About Me

Hi, my name is Daniel and I’m an experienced software engineer with a demonstrated history of delivering commercial software. I’m a strong believer in iterative development, breaking complex requirements into incremental milestones to deliver consistent, predictable results.

Most of my work has involved writing software that drives or interacts with hardware in some way. My current work is creating desktop software for fiber optic test and measurement devices, as well as embedded touchscreen software for a handheld measurement device. In previous jobs I have developed self checkout kiosks for libraries, and firmware for programmable logic controllers used in factory automation.

I am currently working as a Software Engineering Manager at Luna Innovations. I oversee the progress of development projects across multiple locations, while still rolling up my sleeves and writing code.

The things I currently have the most experience work with are: C++, Qt, Qt Widgets, QML, UI design, Linux, Windows, git, github and software project management

Projects

Qt Minesweeper

https://danielmcpherson.github.io/minesweeper/minesweeper.html

A Minesweeper game written in Qt with C++ and Qt Widgets

A fun project to practice and demonstrate my Qt skills. The UI and backend are completely decoupled and communicate only thhrough signals stored in a GameSignals class.

Next steps are to create an alternate user interface in QML for more shininess and to demonstrate connecting the same backend code to a different UI with no backend alterations.

A Qt WebAssembly build of this project is playable online here.

Godot Breakout

https://chucklespmonkeyworth.itch.io/breakout

Breakout written in the Godot Game Engine

A project I wrote while learning the Godot game engine. Godot is a fun, light-weight game engine with a Python-inspired scripting language. I used this project as an opportunity not only to learn Godot but to practice “juicing” the game with particle effects, screen shake, eyes and facial expressions on the controller and ball, and fun animations and transitions. (I also wrote the music!)

Play it on itch.io or gotm.io.

Experience

Luna Innovations, Blacksburg VA

Software Engineering Manager
(2020 - present)
Lead Software Engineer
(2014 - 2020)
Software Engineer
(2004 - 2014)

lunauinc.com

Software development for fiber optic measurement devices using C++, Qt, LabVIEW, Python, Windows, Linux

I develop Windows and Linx desktop and embedded software for fiber optic test and measurement devices. I started Luna as the sole software engineer for the Luna Technologies division, later becoming part of a larger software team and eventually Lead Software Engineer and then Software Engineering Manager for Luna Innovations. I manage software engineers and development projects in multiple locations while continuing to write software, participate in code reviews, and something something.

Plan implementation of new features and release schedules.

In ?year? led the development of a handheld touchscreen measurement device using embedded Phytec Linux, Qt, QML, C++, and Python.

From ?year? to ?year? I led the development of two new product families, one focused on telecommunications and photonics testing, the other using fiber optics to measure strain and temperature. Both use Ubuntu Linux, Windows, Qt (Qt Widgets, QML, Qt Remote Objects, and Qt WebGL), and C++.

I have developed software APIs, TCP/IP data streaming protocols, and SCPI command sets to allow users to control Luna devices and integrate measurements into their own test software.

In my earlier work at Luna, I developed Windows software for fiber optic test devices using a LabVIEW front end calling DLLs written in Microsoft Visual C++.

VTLS, Blacksburg VA

Software Engineer

1996 - 2004

Library software, data conversion, and RFID self checkout stations

VTLS (now part of Innovative Interfaces) produced software for public, corporate, and university librares. I developed software using C#, Python, Clipper, dBase, and Oracle. In particular, I developed database conversion software to map customer data from foreign formats into the MARC (MAchine Readable Cataloging) format used by US libraries.

I managed and led the development of an RFID-based library system, including desktop Windows software, self checkout kiosks, and portable inventory system, using Microsoft Visual C++, C#.NET, and Python.

GE Fanuc, Charlottesville VA

Software Engineer

1994 - 1996

Embedded software for programmable logic controllers

I developed firmware for programmable logic controllers used in factory automation, using C and Intel x86 assembly. I designed and implemented tests of PLCs and their accessories, winning the GE “Silver Dollar” award for my work on Ethernet component testing.

US Naval Surface Warface Center, Dahlgren VA

Electronics Engineer (Co-op)

1990-1994

College co-op engineering job

I developed tools for testing Tomahawk cruise missile launch software, using C and C++. This included a simulator to mimic fleet communications while injecting specific protocol errors required for testing. I held a Secret level security clearance.

Education

Virginia Tech, Blacksburg VA

BSc Computer Engineering

1989-1994

Ut Prosim. Go Hokies!

My computer engineering degree at Virginia Tech taught me solid software design principals and an understanding of how computers work at the digital and electronics level. Among my favorite courses were Digital Design and Microprocessors, which gave me experience working on a team and dealing with memory and timing constraints that were not considered in most progamming classes.

I was active in music programs at Virginia Tech, playing trumpet in the Marching Virginians, the VT Wind Ensemble, and New River Valley Orchestra.

I graduated Cum Laude and In Honors, completing an Honors research project developing color recognition for a computer vision system. In my senior year, I was selected as one of handful of students to participate in VT’s Engineering Abroad project, visiting the Kansai Airport project in Osaka, Japan.

When I'm Not Programming

I play guitar, trumpet, and piano. I play trumpet in The Sauerkraut Band (German Oktoberfest music), and The Figgy Pudding Band (The Sauerkraut Band, but Christmas music), and the Blacksburg Community Band. I have played both guitar and trumpet for the Blacksburg Community Strings Orchestra and in the pit orchestra for Blacksburg Summer Musical Enterprise.

I am an occasional fiction writer with a dozen published short stories including “Collector’s Item” published by Daily Science Fiction.

I’ve had a lifelong unrequited love of chess, despite not being very good at it. You can find me on chess.com.
